You said
I have a database SafeVault, in it I has Table Users like this CREATE TABLE Users ( -> Id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, -> Username VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE, -> PasswordHash VARCHAR(256) NOT NULL, -> Role VARCHAR(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'User' -> ); I also created a dotnet mvc project name SafeVault. Now we do step 1: Can you create me a function name ValidationHelpers to validate input for UserName.
Copilot said

Absolutely and since youre building SafeVault with a proper MVC structure, this is the perfect moment to establish clean, reusable validation logic.

A good ValidationHelpers class should:

  • Enforce allowed characters

  • Enforce length rules

  • Prevent whitespace-only usernames

  • Be reusable across controllers, services, and view models

  • Return clear error messages so the UI can display them

Below is a clean, productionready version you can drop into your project.

ValidationHelpers.cs

csharp
using System.Text.RegularExpressions;

namespace SafeVault.Helpers
{
    public static class ValidationHelpers
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Validates a username based on SafeVault rules.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="username">The username to validate.</param>
        /// <param name="errorMessage">Output error message if validation fails.</param>
        /// <returns>True if valid, false otherwise.</returns>
        public static bool ValidateUsername(string username, out string errorMessage)
        {
            errorMessage = string.Empty;

            if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(username))
            {
                errorMessage = "Username cannot be empty.";
                return false;
            }

            if (username.Length < 3 || username.Length > 50)
            {
                errorMessage = "Username must be between 3 and 50 characters.";
                return false;
            }

            // Allow letters, numbers, underscores, and dots
            var regex = new Regex("^[a-zA-Z0-9._]+$");
            if (!regex.IsMatch(username))
            {
                errorMessage = "Username can only contain letters, numbers, dots, and underscores.";
                return false;
            }

            return true;
        }
    }
}

How to Use It in Your Controller

csharp
using SafeVault.Helpers;

public IActionResult Register(UserRegisterViewModel model)
{
    if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername(model.Username, out string error))
    {
        ModelState.AddModelError("Username", error);
        return View(model);
    }

    // Continue registration...
}

Why This Design Works

  • Static helper easy to call anywhere

  • Regex-based strict control over allowed characters

  • Clear error messages perfect for MVC validation

  • Matches your DB constraint (VARCHAR(50))

  • Prevents invalid or malicious input early

You said
Should Password be validated too ? I thought password should take any key.
Copilot said

Great question and this is one of those areas where beginners often get mixed signals. Youre right that passwords should allow almost any character, but that doesnt mean no validation at all. The trick is understanding what to validate and why.

Lets break it down clearly.

Should passwords be validated?

Yes but not in the same way as usernames.

Usernames need strict validation because theyre identifiers stored in plain text and used in queries.

Passwords are different:

  • They are never stored in plain text

  • They are hashed, so the raw password is never saved

  • They should allow symbols, spaces, unicode, anything

  • They should not be restricted to alphanumeric characters

But you still need validation for:

Minimum security

  • Minimum length (e.g., 8 or 10 characters)

  • Optional: require at least one uppercase, one number, one symbol

  • Optional: block extremely weak passwords like "123456" or "password"

Preventing empty or whitespace-only passwords

  • " " should not be allowed

  • "" should not be allowed

Preventing extremely long passwords

  • You dont want someone sending a 5MB password and causing performance issues

  • A safe upper limit is usually 128 characters

Recommended SafeVault Password Rules

Since SafeVault is a security-focused app, a good baseline is:

  • Length: 8128 characters

  • Allow any characters

  • No other restrictions unless you want stronger policies

Example: Password Validation Helper

csharp
public static bool ValidatePassword(string password, out string errorMessage)
{
    errorMessage = string.Empty;

    if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(password))
    {
        errorMessage = "Password cannot be empty.";
        return false;
    }

    if (password.Length < 8)
    {
        errorMessage = "Password must be at least 8 characters long.";
        return false;
    }

    if (password.Length > 128)
    {
        errorMessage = "Password is too long.";
        return false;
    }

    return true;
}

This keeps things secure without restricting characters.

Why you dont validate characters in passwords

  • Users should be free to use symbols, unicode, emojis, anything

  • Restricting characters makes passwords weaker

  • Hashing protects the stored value anyway

  • Modern hashing algorithms (PBKDF2, bcrypt, Argon2) handle any characters safely

If you want stronger password rules

I can help you add:

  • Uppercase/lowercase/number/symbol requirements

  • Password strength scoring

  • Breached password checking (HaveIBeenPwned API)

  • Custom SafeVault security policies

Just tell me how strict you want SafeVault to be.

Copilot said

Absolutely this gives SafeVault a clean, consistent validation layer right from the start. Heres a polished ValidationHelpers class that enforces exactly the rules you described.

ValidationHelpers.cs

csharp
using System.Text.RegularExpressions;

namespace SafeVault.Helpers
{
    public static class ValidationHelpers
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Validates a username. Allowed characters: letters, numbers, @, #, $.
        /// </summary>
        public static bool ValidateUsername(string username, out string errorMessage)
        {
            errorMessage = string.Empty;

            if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(username))
            {
                errorMessage = "Username cannot be empty.";
                return false;
            }

            if (username.Length < 3 || username.Length > 50)
            {
                errorMessage = "Username must be between 3 and 50 characters.";
                return false;
            }

            // Allowed: AZ, az, 09, @, #, $
            var regex = new Regex("^[a-zA-Z0-9@#$]+$");
            if (!regex.IsMatch(username))
            {
                errorMessage = "Username can only contain letters, numbers, @, #, $.";
                return false;
            }

            return true;
        }

        /// <summary>
        /// Validates a password. Must be 8128 characters and not whitespace-only.
        /// </summary>
        public static bool ValidatePassword(string password, out string errorMessage)
        {
            errorMessage = string.Empty;

            if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(password))
            {
                errorMessage = "Password cannot be empty or whitespace.";
                return false;
            }

            if (password.Length < 8)
            {
                errorMessage = "Password must be at least 8 characters long.";
                return false;
            }

            if (password.Length > 128)
            {
                errorMessage = "Password must be shorter than 128 characters.";
                return false;
            }

            return true;
        }
    }
}

Why this design works well

  • Keeps validation logic centralized

  • Matches your database constraints

  • Username regex is simple and safe

  • Password rules are securityfriendly without restricting characters

  • Easy to plug into controllers, services, or view models

You said
Step 2: Can you generate a function name IsValidXSSInput to check and remove cross-site script?
Copilot said

Youve got the right instinct here SafeVault should absolutely sanitize usersupplied text to prevent XSS. But theres an important nuance:

You cannot reliably detect all XSS with a simple regex. However, you can create a helper that removes the most common dangerous patterns and ensures the input is safe enough for usernames, notes, descriptions, etc.

For SafeVault, a practical and secure approach is:

  • Strip <script> tags

  • Strip HTML tags entirely (since SafeVault doesnt need HTML input)

  • Remove event handlers like onload=, onclick=, etc.

  • Remove JavaScript URLs (javascript:)

  • Trim whitespace

This gives you a strong baseline without overcomplicating things.

IsValidXSSInput Function (SafeVault Version)

csharp
using System.Text.RegularExpressions;

namespace SafeVault.Helpers
{
    public static class ValidationHelpers
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Removes common XSS attack patterns and returns a sanitized string.
        /// </summary>
        public static string SanitizeXSS(string input)
        {
            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(input))
                return string.Empty;

            string sanitized = input;

            // Remove <script> tags
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(sanitized, "<script.*?>.*?</script>", "", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase | RegexOptions.Singleline);

            // Remove all HTML tags
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(sanitized, "<.*?>", "");

            // Remove javascript: URLs
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(sanitized, "javascript:", "", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase);

            // Remove event handlers like onclick=, onload=, etc.
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(sanitized, @"on\w+\s*=", "", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase);

            // Trim whitespace
            sanitized = sanitized.Trim();

            return sanitized;
        }

        /// <summary>
        /// Checks if input contains XSS patterns. Returns true if safe.
        /// </summary>
        public static bool IsValidXSSInput(string input)
        {
            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(input))
                return true;

            // Detect script tags
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, "<script.*?>", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase))
                return false;

            // Detect HTML tags
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, "<.*?>"))
                return false;

            // Detect javascript: URLs
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, "javascript:", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase))
                return false;

            // Detect event handlers
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, @"on\w+\s*=", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase))
                return false;

            return true;
        }
    }
}

How to Use It

Sanitize before saving to DB

csharp
var cleanInput = ValidationHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Description);

Validate before processing

csharp
if (!ValidationHelpers.IsValidXSSInput(model.Description))
{
    ModelState.AddModelError("Description", "Input contains unsafe content.");
    return View(model);
}

Why This Approach Works

  • SafeVault doesnt need HTML input stripping tags is safe

  • Removes the most common XSS vectors

  • Lightweight and fast

  • Easy to extend later

  • Works for usernames, notes, descriptions, comments, etc.

  • Add DataAnnotations for validation

  • Add controller logic for registration

  • Add hashing (PBKDF2) and user creation

So this code is also in ValidationHelpers class ? Does it make project less modular ?
Copilot said

Youre thinking exactly like a real architect now this is the moment where SafeVault starts becoming a professional project instead of a just make it work project.

Lets break it down clearly and avoid overengineering.

Should XSS functions live inside ValidationHelpers?

Short answer: They can, but its not the cleanest longterm structure.

Long answer: ValidationHelpers is meant for input validation:

  • Username rules

  • Password rules

  • Length checks

  • Allowed characters

XSS sanitization is not validation its security filtering.

Those are two different responsibilities.

If you put everything into one class, it works, but youre mixing:

ResponsibilityExamplesShould it be in ValidationHelpers?
Validationusername rules, password rules Yes
Security filteringXSS sanitization, HTML stripping Better separated

So yes putting XSS logic inside ValidationHelpers makes the class less modular and mixes concerns.

A cleaner, more modular structure

Option A (Best Practice)

Create a separate class:

Code
Helpers/
    ValidationHelpers.cs
    SecurityHelpers.cs

  • ValidationHelpers username, password, numeric ranges, etc.

  • SecurityHelpers XSS sanitization, HTML stripping, encoding

This keeps your architecture clean and scalable.

Option B (Still acceptable for small projects)

Keep everything in ValidationHelpers for now, and split later when the project grows.

This is fine if:

  • SafeVault is still small

  • You want simplicity

  • Youre not building a huge enterprise system yet

You can always refactor later.

My recommendation for SafeVault

Given your goals clean architecture, maintainability, and professional polish Id go with:

ValidationHelpers

  • ValidateUsername

  • ValidatePassword

SecurityHelpers

  • SanitizeXSS

  • IsValidXSSInput

This separation keeps your project modular and easy to extend.

Perfect keeping ValidationHelpers focused on pure validation is exactly the right move. Now SafeVault gets a clean, modular structure with a dedicated SecurityHelpers class for sanitization and XSSrelated filtering.

Below is a productionready, clean, and maintainable SecurityHelpers class.

SecurityHelpers.cs

csharp
using System.Text.RegularExpressions;

namespace SafeVault.Helpers
{
    public static class SecurityHelpers
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Sanitizes input by removing common XSS attack patterns.
        /// This is SafeVault's defensive layer for any user-supplied text.
        /// </summary>
        public static string SanitizeXSS(string input)
        {
            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(input))
                return string.Empty;

            string sanitized = input;

            // Remove <script>...</script>
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(
                sanitized,
                "<script.*?>.*?</script>",
                "",
                RegexOptions.IgnoreCase | RegexOptions.Singleline
            );

            // Remove all HTML tags
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(
                sanitized,
                "<.*?>",
                "",
                RegexOptions.IgnoreCase
            );

            // Remove javascript: URLs
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(
                sanitized,
                "javascript:",
                "",
                RegexOptions.IgnoreCase
            );

            // Remove event handlers like onclick=, onload=, etc.
            sanitized = Regex.Replace(
                sanitized,
                @"on\w+\s*=",
                "",
                RegexOptions.IgnoreCase
            );

            // Trim whitespace
            sanitized = sanitized.Trim();

            return sanitized;
        }

        /// <summary>
        /// Checks if input contains unsafe XSS patterns.
        /// Returns true if the input is safe.
        /// </summary>
        public static bool IsValidXSSInput(string input)
        {
            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(input))
                return true;

            // Detect <script> tags
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, "<script.*?>", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase))
                return false;

            // Detect any HTML tags
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, "<.*?>"))
                return false;

            // Detect javascript: URLs
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, "javascript:", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase))
                return false;

            // Detect event handlers like onclick=
            if (Regex.IsMatch(input, @"on\w+\s*=", RegexOptions.IgnoreCase))
                return false;

            return true;
        }
    }
}

Why this structure is clean and modular

ValidationHelpers

  • Username rules

  • Password rules

  • Length checks

  • Allowed characters

SecurityHelpers

  • XSS sanitization

  • HTML stripping

  • Dangerous pattern detection

This separation keeps SafeVaults architecture clean, predictable, and easy to extend.

You said
Where should I place this Register.cshtml? I though it should be in Views folder ?
Copilot said

Youre right that it belongs in the Views folder but MVC has a very specific structure for where each view should live. Lets make it crystal clear so your SafeVault project stays clean and professional.

Where Register.cshtml Should Go

In ASP.NET MVC, views are grouped by controller name.

If your registration logic is inside:

AccountController.cs

Then the correct folder is:

Code
/Views
    /Account
        Register.cshtml

If your controller is named something else (e.g., AuthController), then the folder must match:

Code
/Views
    /Auth
        Register.cshtml

Why it must be inside a controllernamed folder

MVC uses convention over configuration:

  • Controller name: AccountController

  • Action name: Register()

  • Expected view path: /Views/Account/Register.cshtml

If the folder name doesnt match the controller name, MVC wont find the view unless you manually specify a path which you dont want.

Example Folder Structure for SafeVault

Code
SafeVault/

 Controllers/
      AccountController.cs

 Models/
      UserRegisterViewModel.cs

 Helpers/
      ValidationHelpers.cs
      SecurityHelpers.cs

 Views/
      Account/
           Register.cshtml
      Shared/
           _Layout.cshtml
           _ValidationScriptsPartial.cshtml

 wwwroot/

This is the clean, standard MVC layout.

You said
This step 3 is not right. Let's do it again. Step 3: Can you create me HashingHelper to hash and verify password ?
Copilot said

Nice resetthats a much better Step 3 for SafeVault.

Heres a clean HashingHelper that:

  • Generates a random salt

  • Uses PBKDF2 (Rfc2898DeriveBytes)

  • Stores salt + hash together as Base64

  • Verifies passwords safely

Place this in Helpers/HashingHelper.cs.

HashingHelper.cs

csharp
using System.Security.Cryptography;
using System.Text;

namespace SafeVault.Helpers
{
    public static class HashingHelper
    {
        // You can tweak these if needed
        private const int SaltSize = 16;      // 128-bit
        private const int KeySize = 32;       // 256-bit
        private const int Iterations = 100_000;

        /// <summary>
        /// Hashes a password using PBKDF2 with a random salt.
        /// Returns a Base64 string containing salt + hash.
        /// </summary>
        public static string HashPassword(string password)
        {
            if (password == null)
                throw new ArgumentNullException(nameof(password));

            using var rng = RandomNumberGenerator.Create();
            byte[] salt = new byte[SaltSize];
            rng.GetBytes(salt);

            using var pbkdf2 = new Rfc2898DeriveBytes(password, salt, Iterations, HashAlgorithmName.SHA256);
            byte[] key = pbkdf2.GetBytes(KeySize);

            // Combine salt + key into one array
            byte[] result = new byte[SaltSize + KeySize];
            Buffer.BlockCopy(salt, 0, result, 0, SaltSize);
            Buffer.BlockCopy(key, 0, result, SaltSize, KeySize);

            return Convert.ToBase64String(result);
        }

        /// <summary>
        /// Verifies a password against a stored Base64(salt+hash) string.
        /// </summary>
        public static bool VerifyPassword(string password, string storedHash)
        {
            if (password == null)
                throw new ArgumentNullException(nameof(password));
            if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(storedHash))
                return false;

            byte[] storedBytes;

            try
            {
                storedBytes = Convert.FromBase64String(storedHash);
            }
            catch
            {
                // Not a valid Base64 string
                return false;
            }

            if (storedBytes.Length != SaltSize + KeySize)
                return false;

            byte[] salt = new byte[SaltSize];
            byte[] storedKey = new byte[KeySize];

            Buffer.BlockCopy(storedBytes, 0, salt, 0, SaltSize);
            Buffer.BlockCopy(storedBytes, SaltSize, storedKey, 0, KeySize);

            using var pbkdf2 = new Rfc2898DeriveBytes(password, salt, Iterations, HashAlgorithmName.SHA256);
            byte[] computedKey = pbkdf2.GetBytes(KeySize);

            // Constant-time comparison
            return CryptographicOperations.FixedTimeEquals(storedKey, computedKey);
        }
    }
}

If you want next, we can wire this into:

  • The registration flow (hash before insert), and

  • The login flow (verify against DB value).

You said
We dont use secrete key in HashingHelper ,do we ?
Copilot said

Great question and this is exactly the kind of thing that separates hashing from encryption, so its good youre thinking about it.

Short answer:

No. Hashing does NOT use a secret key. And your HashingHelper is 100% correct without one.

Why hashing does NOT use a secret key

Hashing is a oneway operation:

  • You take a password

  • Combine it with a random salt

  • Run it through PBKDF2

  • Store the result

There is no key because you never decrypt anything. You only recompute the hash and compare.

This is why hashing is safe even if someone steals your database they still cannot reverse the hash.

When do we use a secret key?

A secret key is used in:

1. Encryption

  • AES

  • RSA

  • ChaCha20

  • etc. Encryption is reversible, so it needs a key.

2. HMAC (keyed hashing)

  • HMACSHA256

  • HMACSHA512 Used for:

  • JWT signatures

  • API authentication

  • Message integrity

But password hashing does NOT use HMAC.

What PBKDF2 uses instead

PBKDF2 uses:

  • A random salt (prevents rainbow table attacks)

  • A high iteration count (slows down brute force)

  • A hash algorithm (SHA256, SHA512, etc.)

This is exactly what your HashingHelper is doing.

Your HashingHelper is correct

Your implementation:

  • Generates a random salt

  • Uses PBKDF2 with SHA256

  • Uses 100,000 iterations

  • Stores salt + hash together

  • Verifies using constanttime comparison

This is industrystandard and secure.

Copilot said

If you want the cleanest, leastpainful development flow, theres a correct order for building JWT authentication + rolebased authorization. And its not arbitrary one depends on the other.

Lets break it down in a way that fits your SafeVault architecture.

The correct order is:

1 Build JWT Authentication first

2 Add Rolebased Authorization after

Why JWT must come first

Rolebased authorization depends on claims inside the JWT.

A JWT typically contains:

  • sub user ID

  • username

  • role "Admin" or "User"

  • expiration

  • issuer / audience

If you dont have JWT authentication working yet, then:

  • You have no token

  • You have no claims

  • You have no identity

  • You have no role to authorize

So authorization literally has nothing to work with.

The correct build sequence (SafeVault version)

Step 1 Build JWT Authentication

  • Create JwtSettings (Issuer, Audience, SecretKey, Expiration)

  • Create JwtTokenHelper to generate tokens

  • Add authentication middleware in Program.cs

  • Add login endpoint that returns a JWT

Once this is done, you can log in and receive a token like:

Code
eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...

And inside that token will be:

Code
{
  "sub": "1",
  "username": "hoang",
  "role": "Admin"
}

Now you have something to authorize.

Step 2 Add RoleBased Authorization

Once JWT is working, you add:

  • [Authorize]

  • [Authorize(Roles = "Admin")]

  • [Authorize(Roles = "User")]

And ASP.NET Core will automatically read the role claim from the JWT.

A simple analogy

JWT authentication = your ID card Role authorization = the door that checks your access level

You cant check access level if you dont have an ID card yet.

So the answer is:

**Start with JWT Authentication.

Then add Rolebased Authorization.**

Copilot said

Youre building SafeVault the right way, Hoang clean helpers, clean architecture, and now a clean JWT generator. Heres a productionready JWTHelpers.cs that:

  • Generates a JWT

  • Embeds username and role

  • Sets expiration

  • Uses a secret key from configuration

  • Produces a compact, signed token

This fits perfectly into your MVC project structure.

Helpers/JWTHelpers.cs

csharp
using System;
using System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt;
using System.Security.Claims;
using System.Text;
using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens;

namespace SafeVault.Helpers
{
    public static class JWTHelpers
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Generates a JWT token containing username and role.
        /// </summary>
        public static string GenerateToken(
            string username,
            string role,
            string secretKey,
            string issuer,
            string audience,
            int expirationMinutes = 60)
        {
            var key = new SymmetricSecurityKey(Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(secretKey));
            var creds = new SigningCredentials(key, SecurityAlgorithms.HmacSha256);

            var claims = new[]
            {
                new Claim(JwtRegisteredClaimNames.Sub, username),
                new Claim("role", role),
                new Claim(JwtRegisteredClaimNames.Jti, Guid.NewGuid().ToString())
            };

            var token = new JwtSecurityToken(
                issuer: issuer,
                audience: audience,
                claims: claims,
                expires: DateTime.UtcNow.AddMinutes(expirationMinutes),
                signingCredentials: creds
            );

            return new JwtSecurityTokenHandler().WriteToken(token);
        }
    }
}

How this works

Claims included

  • sub username

  • role used by [Authorize(Roles = "...")]

  • jti unique token ID

Expiration

Default: 60 minutes You can change it per call.

Signing

Uses HMAC SHA256 with your secret key.

Example usage inside your Login action

csharp
string token = JWTHelpers.GenerateToken(
    username: user.Username,
    role: user.Role,
    secretKey: _config["Jwt:SecretKey"],
    issuer: _config["Jwt:Issuer"],
    audience: _config["Jwt:Audience"],
    expirationMinutes: 60
);

Your appsettings.json should contain:

json
"Jwt": {
  "SecretKey": "YOUR_SUPER_SECRET_KEY_123456789",
  "Issuer": "SafeVault",
  "Audience": "SafeVaultUsers"
}

To generate and validate JWTs in .NET, you need one specific NuGet package:

And usually you install this one alongside it:

Code

These two packages give you:

  • JwtSecurityTokenHandler

  • SigningCredentials

  • SecurityAlgorithms

  • Claim

  • TokenValidationParameters

All the types used in your JWTHelpers.cs.

using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens;

These namespaces are not included in a default MVC project, so without the packages, VS Code will show errors like:

Installing the packages fixes all of that instantly.

Step 5 Configure JWT Authentication in Program.cs

Add this inside your Program.cs:

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer;
using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens;
using System.Text;

Then add this block before builder.Build():

csharp
var jwtSettings = builder.Configuration.GetSection("Jwt");
var secretKey = jwtSettings["SecretKey"];

builder.Services.AddAuthentication(options =>
{
    options.DefaultAuthenticateScheme = JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme;
    options.DefaultChallengeScheme = JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme;
})
.AddJwtBearer(options =>
{
    options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters
    {
        ValidateIssuer = true,
        ValidateAudience = true,
        ValidateLifetime = true,
        ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,

        ValidIssuer = jwtSettings["Issuer"],
        ValidAudience = jwtSettings["Audience"],
        IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(secretKey)),

        ClockSkew = TimeSpan.Zero // No extra time added to expiration
    };
});

Finally, enable authentication + authorization in the pipeline:

csharp
var app = builder.Build();

app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

Make sure these two lines appear before your route mappings.

Your appsettings.json should contain:

json
"Jwt": {
  "SecretKey": "YOUR_SUPER_SECRET_KEY_123456789",
  "Issuer": "SafeVault",
  "Audience": "SafeVaultUsers"
}

Use a long, random secret key (32+ characters).

What this configuration does

Validates the token signature

Ensures the JWT was created using your secret key.

Validates issuer + audience

Prevents tokens from other systems from being accepted.

Validates expiration

Expired tokens are rejected.

Extracts claims

ASP.NET Core automatically reads:

  • sub username

  • role used by [Authorize(Roles = "...")]

Enables [Authorize] attributes

Now you can protect controllers like:

Welcome back, Hoang lets build this properly. Step 6 is where SafeVault finally becomes a real authentication system. Below is a clean, productionready Login endpoint that includes every requirement you listed:

Ill give you a complete, realistic AuthController login action that fits perfectly with the helpers you already built.

AuthController.cs Login Endpoint

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc;
using SafeVault.Helpers;
using SafeVault.Models;
using SafeVault.Data; // Your DbContext namespace
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;

namespace SafeVault.Controllers
{
    public class AuthController : Controller
    {
        private readonly ApplicationDbContext _db;
        private readonly IConfiguration _config;

        public AuthController(ApplicationDbContext db, IConfiguration config)
        {
            _db = db;
            _config = config;
        }

        [HttpGet]
        public IActionResult Login()
        {
            return View();
        }

        [HttpPost]
        public async Task<IActionResult> Login(LoginViewModel model)
        {
            // 1. XSS sanitization
            model.Username = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Username);
            model.Password = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Password);

            // 2. Username validation
            if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername(model.Username, out string userError))
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Username", userError);
                return View(model);
            }

            // 3. Password validation
            if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword(model.Password, out string passError))
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Password", passError);
                return View(model);
            }

            // 4. Database lookup
            var user = await _db.Users
                .FirstOrDefaultAsync(u => u.Username == model.Username);

            if (user == null)
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("", "Invalid username or password.");
                return View(model);
            }

            // 5. Hash verification
            bool isPasswordValid = HashingHelper.VerifyPassword(model.Password, user.PasswordHash);

            if (!isPasswordValid)
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("", "Invalid username or password.");
                return View(model);
            }

            // 6. JWT generation
            string token = JWTHelpers.GenerateToken(
                username: user.Username,
                role: user.Role,
                secretKey: _config["Jwt:SecretKey"],
                issuer: _config["Jwt:Issuer"],
                audience: _config["Jwt:Audience"],
                expirationMinutes: 60
            );

            // 7. Return token (JSON)
            return Json(new
            {
                success = true,
                token = token,
                username = user.Username,
                role = user.Role
            });
        }
    }
}

What this endpoint does

1. Sanitizes input

Prevents XSS before doing anything else.

2. Validates username

Uses your ValidationHelpers.

3. Validates password

Ensures length rules are correct.

4. Looks up the user

Queries your database by username.

5. Verifies password hash

Uses your PBKDF2 HashingHelper.

6. Generates JWT

Includes:

  • username

  • role

  • expiration

  • issuer

  • audience

7. Returns JSON token

Perfect for API clients, mobile apps, or Blazor.

If you want a UI login page.

What is the Data folder for?

In ASP.NET Core MVC projects, the Data folder is the conventional place to store:

1. Your DbContext class

This is the heart of Entity Framework Core. Example:

csharp
public class ApplicationDbContext : DbContext
{
    public DbSet<User> Users { get; set; }
}

2. Your database models (optional)

Some developers put models here, but most keep them in a Models folder. Either is fine consistency is what matters.

3. EF Core Migrations

When you run:

Code
dotnet ef migrations add InitialCreate

EF will generate:

Code
/Data/Migrations/20240205_InitialCreate.cs

This folder keeps your schema history organized.

4. Seed data (optional)

If you want to insert default admin users or roles, you can put seeding logic here.

Why the folder doesnt exist yet

Because you havent created it Visual Studio Code doesnt autogenerate it.

In Visual Studio (full IDE), some templates create it automatically. In VS Code, you create it manually.

Great question, Hoang and this is one of those details that can feel confusing the first time you set up EF Core with SQL Server. Lets clear it up cleanly.

Do you need to put SQL Server login info in appsettings.json?

Only if your SQL Server requires a username + password.

There are two ways to connect:

Option 1 Windows Authentication (Trusted_Connection=True)

This is what youre using right now:

json
"DefaultConnection": "Server=localhost;Database=SafeVaultDB;Trusted_Connection=True;TrustServerCertificate=True;"

This means:

  • SQL Server uses your Windows account to authenticate

  • No username/password needed

  • Works perfectly on your local machine

  • Easiest setup

If SQL Server is running under your Windows user, this is all you need.

Option 2 SQL Authentication (username + password)

If your SQL Server instance requires a login (e.g., sa), then yes you must include it:

json
"DefaultConnection": "Server=localhost;Database=SafeVaultDB;User Id=sa;Password=YourPassword123;TrustServerCertificate=True;"

This is required when:

  • You installed SQL Server with mixed mode authentication

  • You created a SQL login

  • Youre connecting from another machine

  • Youre deploying to a server

Which one should YOU use for SafeVault?

Since you're developing locally and keeping things simple:

Use Windows Authentication (Trusted_Connection=True)

No need to store passwords. No need to expose credentials. No need to modify anything.

Your current connection string is perfect.

Security Tip

If you ever switch to SQL Authentication:

  • Never commit passwords to GitHub

  • Use environment variables or user secrets for production

  • Keep appsettings.json clean for local development

If you want, I can show you how to use User Secrets to hide your DB password safely.

You said
We don't specify Table name in appsettings.json , do we ?
Copilot said

Great question, Hoang and this is one of those things that confuses a lot of developers when they first work with EF Core + MySQL.

Lets make it crystal clear.

No you do NOT specify the table name in appsettings.json

appsettings.json only stores connection information:

  • Server

  • Database name

  • Username

  • Password

  • Port (optional)

It never stores:

  • Table names

  • Column names

  • Schema details

  • Entity mappings

Those belong in your DbContext and entity classes, not in configuration.

Where does EF Core get the table name from?

From your entity class and DbContext.

You created:

csharp
public class User
{
    public int Id { get; set; }
    public string Username { get; set; }
    public string PasswordHash { get; set; }
    public string Role { get; set; }
}

And in your ApplicationDbContext:

csharp
public DbSet<User> Users { get; set; }

EF Core automatically maps:

  • Entity name User

  • DbSet name Users

  • to table name Users

This matches your MySQL table perfectly.

Your MySQL table is already correct

Since youre using MySQL, your table:

sql
CREATE TABLE Users (
    Id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    Username VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    PasswordHash VARCHAR(256) NOT NULL,
    Role VARCHAR(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'User'
);

Matches your entity Matches your DbSet Matches EF Core conventions No need to drop it No need to recreate it

Youre good.

Your appsettings.json should ONLY contain the database name

Example:

json
"ConnectionStrings": {
  "DefaultConnection": "Server=localhost;Database=SafeVault;User Id=root;Password=MyPassword123;"
}

Thats it.

Summary

ThingWhere it goes
Database nameappsettings.json
Server, username, passwordappsettings.json
Table nameEntity + DbContext
Column namesEntity class
Schema rulesEntity class or Fluent API

So no you never put table names in appsettings.json.

Alright Hoang Step 9 is a big one. This is where SafeVault becomes a real system that can create users, store hashed passwords, and assign roles. Well build a clean, secure, productionready Register endpoint that matches everything youve built so far.

Heres what this endpoint will include:

  • Role assignment

  • Database insert

AuthController.cs Register Endpoint

Add this inside your AuthController:

csharp
[HttpGet]
public IActionResult Register()
{
    return View();
}

[HttpPost]
public async Task<IActionResult> Register(RegisterViewModel model)
{
    // 1. XSS sanitization
    model.Username = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Username);
    model.Password = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Password);

    // 2. Username validation
    if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername(model.Username, out string userError))
    {
        ModelState.AddModelError("Username", userError);
        return View(model);
    }

    // 3. Password validation
    if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword(model.Password, out string passError))
    {
        ModelState.AddModelError("Password", passError);
        return View(model);
    }

    // 4. Check if username already exists
    bool exists = await _db.Users.AnyAsync(u => u.Username == model.Username);
    if (exists)
    {
        ModelState.AddModelError("Username", "This username is already taken.");
        return View(model);
    }

    // 5. Hash password
    string hashedPassword = HashingHelper.HashPassword(model.Password);

    // 6. Create user entity
    var user = new User
    {
        Username = model.Username,
        PasswordHash = hashedPassword,
        Role = "User" // default role
    };

    // 7. Save to database
    _db.Users.Add(user);
    await _db.SaveChangesAsync();

    // 8. Return success JSON
    return Json(new
    {
        success = true,
        message = "Registration successful. You can now log in."
    });
}

RegisterViewModel.cs

Create this file in Models/:

csharp
namespace SafeVault.Models
{
    public class RegisterViewModel
    {
        public string Username { get; set; } = string.Empty;

        public string Password { get; set; } = string.Empty;
    }
}

Simple, clean, and consistent with your LoginViewModel.

Why this Register endpoint is correct

Sanitizes input

Checks for duplicates

Prevents duplicate usernames in MySQL.

Hashes password

Uses your PBKDF2 HashingHelper.

Inserts into MySQL

Works with your existing Users table.

Returns JSON

Perfect for API, Blazor, mobile, or MVC.

Updated AuthController.cs (Login + Register)

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc;
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;
using SafeVault.Data;
using SafeVault.Helpers;
using SafeVault.Models;

namespace SafeVault.Controllers
{
    public class AuthController : Controller
    {
        private readonly ApplicationDbContext _db;
        private readonly IConfiguration _config;

        public AuthController(ApplicationDbContext db, IConfiguration config)
        {
            _db = db;
            _config = config;
        }

        // ============================
        // LOGIN (GET)
        // ============================
        [HttpGet]
        public IActionResult Login()
        {
            return View();
        }

        // ============================
        // LOGIN (POST)
        // ============================
        [HttpPost]
        public async Task<IActionResult> Login(LoginViewModel model)
        {
            // 1. XSS sanitization
            model.Username = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Username);
            model.Password = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Password);

            // 2. Username validation
            if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername(model.Username, out string userError))
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Username", userError);
                return View(model);
            }

            // 3. Password validation
            if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword(model.Password, out string passError))
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Password", passError);
                return View(model);
            }

            // 4. Database lookup
            var user = await _db.Users.FirstOrDefaultAsync(u => u.Username == model.Username);

            if (user == null)
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("", "Invalid username or password.");
                return View(model);
            }

            // 5. Hash verification
            bool isPasswordValid = HashingHelper.VerifyPassword(model.Password, user.PasswordHash);

            if (!isPasswordValid)
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("", "Invalid username or password.");
                return View(model);
            }

            // 6. JWT generation
            string token = JWTHelpers.GenerateToken(
                username: user.Username,
                role: user.Role,
                secretKey: _config["Jwt:SecretKey"],
                issuer: _config["Jwt:Issuer"],
                audience: _config["Jwt:Audience"],
                expirationMinutes: 60
            );

            // 7. Return token (JSON)
            return Json(new
            {
                success = true,
                token = token,
                username = user.Username,
                role = user.Role
            });
        }

        // ============================
        // REGISTER (GET)
        // ============================
        [HttpGet]
        public IActionResult Register()
        {
            return View();
        }

        // ============================
        // REGISTER (POST)
        // ============================
        [HttpPost]
        public async Task<IActionResult> Register(RegisterViewModel model)
        {
            // 1. XSS sanitization
            model.Username = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Username);
            model.Password = SecurityHelpers.SanitizeXSS(model.Password);

            // 2. Username validation
            if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername(model.Username, out string userError))
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Username", userError);
                return View(model);
            }

            // 3. Password validation
            if (!ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword(model.Password, out string passError))
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Password", passError);
                return View(model);
            }

            // 4. Check if username already exists
            bool exists = await _db.Users.AnyAsync(u => u.Username == model.Username);
            if (exists)
            {
                ModelState.AddModelError("Username", "This username is already taken.");
                return View(model);
            }

            // 5. Hash password
            string hashedPassword = HashingHelper.HashPassword(model.Password);

            // 6. Create user entity
            var user = new User
            {
                Username = model.Username,
                PasswordHash = hashedPassword,
                Role = "User"
            };

            // 7. Save to database
            _db.Users.Add(user);
            await _db.SaveChangesAsync();

            // 8. Return success JSON
            return Json(new
            {
                success = true,
                message = "Registration successful. You can now log in."
            });
        }
    }
}

You said
LoginViewModel and RegisterViewModel have the same content. Why do we make 2 classes ?
Copilot said

Great observation, Hoang and this is exactly the kind of architectural thinking that makes your codebase clean and scalable.

You're right: LoginViewModel and RegisterViewModel currently have the same two fields:

  • Username

  • Password

So why bother creating two separate classes?

Let me give you the real, professionalgrade reasoning.

Reason 1 They represent different intentions

Even if the fields match today, the meaning of each model is different:

  • LoginViewModel authenticating an existing user

  • RegisterViewModel creating a new user

In MVC, ViewModels are not about fields theyre about intent.

Keeping them separate avoids confusion and keeps your controller actions clean and expressive.

Reason 2 They will diverge later

Registration almost always grows over time.

You might later add:

  • ConfirmPassword

  • Email

  • Phone

  • DisplayName

  • TermsAccepted

  • Captcha

  • Role selection (Admin/User)

  • Security questions

  • 2FA setup

Login rarely changes it stays username + password.

If you merge them now, youll eventually have to split them later, which causes:

  • Breaking changes

  • Refactoring views

  • Refactoring controllers

  • Possible bugs

By separating them now, you futureproof your architecture.

Reason 3 MVC best practice

In ASP.NET Core MVC:

  • Each View gets its own ViewModel

  • Each action gets its own ViewModel

  • ViewModels are NOT reused across different screens

This keeps:

  • Views clean

  • Controllers clean

  • Validation clean

  • Responsibilities separated

This is exactly how professional ASP.NET Core apps are structured.

Reason 4 Security clarity

Login and Register have different security concerns:

Login:

  • Verify password

  • Generate JWT

Register:

  • Validate password strength

  • Hash password

  • Prevent duplicate usernames

Keeping separate ViewModels makes it clear which logic belongs where.

Reason 5 Cleaner Razor Views

Your Razor pages will be:

  • Login.cshtml uses LoginViewModel

  • Register.cshtml uses RegisterViewModel

If you reused one model, youd end up with:

  • Hidden fields

  • Conditional UI

  • Confusing form bindings

Separate ViewModels = clean UI.

Final Answer

Even though they look identical today, LoginViewModel and RegisterViewModel should always be separate.

Its not about the fields its about:

  • Intent

  • Clean architecture

  • Future expansion

You said
Step 12: Add logout functionality
Copilot said

Step 12 is a nice, clean one and it completes the core authentication loop. Right now you can register and log in, but you have no way to log out. Lets fix that in a clean, professional MVC way.

Because youre using JWT, logout is a bit different from cookiebased MVC. JWTs are stateless, meaning:

  • The server does NOT store them

  • The client (browser/app) stores them

  • Logging out simply means deleting the token on the client

But we still create a Logout endpoint so your UI has a proper action to call.

Lets build it.

Add Logout to AuthController

Add this inside your AuthController:

csharp
[HttpPost]
public IActionResult Logout()
{
    // For JWT-based auth, logout simply means:
    // - Client deletes the token
    // - Server returns a success response

    return Json(new
    {
        success = true,
        message = "Logged out successfully."
    });
}

No database needed

No token blacklist needed (unless you want advanced security)

Clean and simple

Your frontend (or Razor page) will simply delete the stored JWT.

Add Logout Button in Your Layout (Optional)

If you have a shared layout like _Layout.cshtml, you can add:

cshtml
<form asp-controller="Auth" asp-action="Logout" method="post" class="d-inline">
    <button type="submit" class="btn btn-link">Logout</button>
</form>

This will POST to /Auth/Logout.

If you want a redirect after logout

You can do this instead:

csharp
[HttpPost]
public IActionResult Logout()
{
    // Client should delete JWT, then redirect to Login page
    return RedirectToAction("Login", "Auth");
}

But remember: Redirect does NOT delete the JWT your client must still remove it.

How Logout Works in JWT Systems

JWT logout is always clientside:

  • Browser localStorage removes the token

  • Mobile app deletes the token

  • Blazor WASM deletes the token

  • MVC page deletes the token from cookies (if you stored it there)

The server cannot invalidate a JWT unless you implement:

  • Token blacklist

  • Token versioning

  • Revocation table

You dont need that for SafeVault right now.

Copilot said

You got it, Hoang redirecting to the Login page after logout is very simple, and it fits perfectly with your MVC flow.

Because youre using JWT, the server doesnt invalidate anything it just tells the client to delete the token. But for MVC navigation, you still want a clean redirect.

Lets update your Logout action to do exactly that.

Updated Logout Action (Redirect to Login)

Replace your current Logout method with this:

csharp
[HttpPost]
public IActionResult Logout()
{
    // Client should delete the JWT token.
    // Server redirects to Login page.
    return RedirectToAction("Login", "Auth");
}

Redirects the user to /Auth/Login

Works with your Dashboard logout button

Keeps the flow clean and intuitive

Important reminder about JWT logout

Redirecting does NOT delete the JWT automatically.

Your client (browser, JS, or app) must remove the token from:

  • localStorage

  • sessionStorage

  • cookies

  • wherever you stored it

But the redirect gives the user a clean UI experience.

When clicked:

  1. POST /Auth/Logout

  2. Server redirects /Auth/Login

  3. Client deletes JWT

Copilot said

Alright Hoang Step 14 is where SafeVault gets its first Adminonly endpoint, protected by rolebased authorization. This is a core feature of any real authentication system, and you already have everything needed: JWT with roles, a Role column in MySQL, and [Authorize].

Lets build this cleanly and professionally.

1. Enable Role-Based Authorization in Program.cs

Make sure your authentication setup includes:

csharp
builder.Services.AddAuthentication("Bearer")
    .AddJwtBearer("Bearer", options =>
    {
        options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters
        {
            ValidateIssuer = true,
            ValidateAudience = true,
            ValidateLifetime = true,
            ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,
            ValidIssuer = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Issuer"],
            ValidAudience = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Audience"],
            IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(
                Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(builder.Configuration["Jwt:SecretKey"]))
        };
    });

And:

csharp
app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

You already have this just confirming.

2. Create AdminController (Adminonly access)

Create:

Code
Controllers/AdminController.cs

Paste this:

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authorization;
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc;

namespace SafeVault.Controllers
{
    [Authorize(Roles = "Admin")]
    public class AdminController : Controller
    {
        public IActionResult Index()
        {
            return View();
        }
    }
}

Only users with Role = "Admin" can access this controller

If a normal user tries 403 Forbidden

If not logged in redirected to Login

3. Create Admin Dashboard View

Create:

Code
Views/Admin/Index.cshtml

Paste this:

cshtml

    ViewData["Title"] = "Admin Dashboard";

    <p>Only Admin users can see this page.</p>

    <form asp-controller="Auth" asp-action="Logout" method="post">
        <button type="submit" class="btn btn-danger mt-3">Logout</button>
    </form>
</div>

Clean

Protected

Includes Logout button

4. How to Make a User an Admin

In MySQL, run:

sql
UPDATE Users
SET Role = 'Admin'
WHERE Username = 'yourusername';

Or insert a new admin:

sql
INSERT INTO Users (Username, PasswordHash, Role)
VALUES ('admin', 'HASHED_PASSWORD_HERE', 'Admin');

If you want, I can generate a hashed password for you.

5. How Authorization Works Now

When a user logs in:

Your JWT includes:

json
{
  "username": "hoang",
  "role": "Admin"
}

When accessing /Admin/Index:

ASP.NET Core checks:

  • Is the JWT valid?

  • Does it contain "role": "Admin"?

If yes access granted If no 403 Forbidden

You said
When I click login or register . This error occurs Program.cs + options.UseMySql(
Copilot said

Ahh, this is a classic one and it almost always happens right after switching from SQL Server to MySQL. When you click Login or Register, MVC tries to load your DbContext, and the error points to:

Code
Program.cs
+ options.UseMySql(

This tells me your MySQL EF Core configuration is incomplete or mismatched.

Lets fix it cleanly.

1. Make sure you installed the correct MySQL provider

You MUST install Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql (not Oracles provider).

Run this:

Code
dotnet add package Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql

If this package is missing, UseMySql() will throw errors.

2. Your Program.cs must use the correct MySQL configuration

Here is the correct, working version for EF Core 7/8:

csharp
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;
using SafeVault.Data;

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

// Add DbContext with MySQL
builder.Services.AddDbContext<ApplicationDbContext>(options =>
{
    options.UseMySql(
        builder.Configuration.GetConnectionString("DefaultConnection"),
        new MySqlServerVersion(new Version(8, 0, 34))
    );
});

builder.Services.AddControllersWithViews();

var app = builder.Build();

app.UseStaticFiles();
app.UseRouting();

app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

app.MapControllerRoute(
    name: "default",
    pattern: "{controller=Home}/{action=Index}/{id?}"
);

app.Run();

Common mistakes that cause your error:

  • Missing new MySqlServerVersion(...)

  • Using SQL Server provider accidentally

  • Using Oracles MySQL provider (not compatible)

  • Wrong package version

  • Missing using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;

3. Your appsettings.json must match MySQL

json
"ConnectionStrings": {
  "DefaultConnection": "Server=localhost;Database=SafeVault;User Id=root;Password=YOUR_PASSWORD;"
}

No port needed unless you changed it.

4. The most common cause of your exact error

If you see something like:

Code
System.InvalidOperationException: Unable to find provider 'UseMySql'

It means:

Pomelo package is not installed Or the version is incompatible with your .NET version

Great news, Hoang your MySQL version (8.0.44) is perfectly fine. Pomelo supports all MySQL 8.x versions, including 8.0.44, 8.0.34, 8.0.32, etc. So your MySQL version is NOT the problem.

The real issue is exactly what you noticed:

builder.Services.AddControllersWithViews();

Without it, MVC cannot render views like Login.cshtml or Register.cshtml, and the app crashes when you click those pages.

Correct Program.cs for MySQL + MVC

Here is the clean, working version you should use:

csharp
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;
using SafeVault.Data;

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

// Add MVC
builder.Services.AddControllersWithViews();

// Add DbContext with MySQL
builder.Services.AddDbContext<ApplicationDbContext>(options =>
{
    options.UseMySql(
        builder.Configuration.GetConnectionString("DefaultConnection"),
        new MySqlServerVersion(new Version(8, 0, 44)) // Your version is perfect
    );
});

// Add Authentication + Authorization (JWT)
builder.Services.AddAuthentication("Bearer")
    .AddJwtBearer("Bearer", options =>
    {
        options.TokenValidationParameters = new()
        {
            ValidateIssuer = true,
            ValidateAudience = true,
            ValidateLifetime = true,
            ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,
            ValidIssuer = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Issuer"],
            ValidAudience = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Audience"],
            IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(
                System.Text.Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(builder.Configuration["Jwt:SecretKey"]))
        };
    });

var app = builder.Build();

app.UseStaticFiles();
app.UseRouting();

app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

app.MapControllerRoute(
    name: "default",
    pattern: "{controller=Home}/{action=Index}/{id?}"
);

app.Run();

Your Corrected Program.cs (Copy & Paste)

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer;
using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens;
using System.Text;
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;
using SafeVault.Data;

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

// Add MVC
builder.Services.AddControllersWithViews();

// Load JWT settings
var jwtSettings = builder.Configuration.GetSection("Jwt");
var secretKey = jwtSettings["SecretKey"];

// Add JWT Authentication
builder.Services.AddAuthentication(options =>
{
    options.DefaultAuthenticateScheme = JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme;
    options.DefaultChallengeScheme = JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme;
})
.AddJwtBearer(options =>
{
    options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters
    {
        ValidateIssuer = true,
        ValidateAudience = true,
        ValidateLifetime = true,
        ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,

        ValidIssuer = jwtSettings["Issuer"],
        ValidAudience = jwtSettings["Audience"],
        IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(secretKey)),

        ClockSkew = TimeSpan.Zero
    };
});

// Add MySQL DbContext
builder.Services.AddDbContext<ApplicationDbContext>(options =>
{
    options.UseMySql(
        builder.Configuration.GetConnectionString("DefaultConnection"),
        new MySqlServerVersion(new Version(8, 0, 44)) // Your MySQL version
    );
});

var app = builder.Build();

// Error handling
if (!app.Environment.IsDevelopment())
{
    app.UseExceptionHandler("/Home/Error");
    app.UseHsts();
}

app.UseHttpsRedirection();
app.UseStaticFiles();

// Correct middleware order
app.UseRouting();
app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

// MVC routing
app.MapControllerRoute(
    name: "default",
    pattern: "{controller=Home}/{action=Index}/{id?}"
);

app.Run();

Removed duplicate UseAuthorization()

You had it twice that can break routing.

Corrected middleware order

The correct order is:

  1. UseRouting()

  2. UseAuthentication()

  3. UseAuthorization()

Ensured MVC is enabled

You already added:

csharp
builder.Services.AddControllersWithViews();

This is required for Login/Register views.

Cleaned up static assets mapping

Your previous MapStaticAssets() was unnecessary.

Copilot said

This message from VS Code looks scary, but its actually harmless it just means:

The file on disk changed after you opened it. Do you want to keep your version or compare them?

This usually happens when:

  • NuGet autoupdated the file in the background

  • VS Code autoformatted the file

  • You edited the file while a restore was running

  • Git or another process touched the file

Let me make this simple for you.

What you should choose right now

Click Overwrite

Why?

Because you intentionally edited the .csproj, and you want your version to be saved.

The newer file warning is just VS Code being cautious it doesnt mean your file is wrong.

When should you choose Compare?

Choose Compare only if:

  • You didnt expect the file to change

  • You want to see what NuGet or Git modified

  • You want to manually merge changes

But in your case, you know youre fixing the file, so Overwrite is the correct choice.

After clicking Overwrite

Once the file is saved:

Code
dotnet clean
dotnet restore

  1. Then run:

dotnet list package

Now the package list will show correctly again.

    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Relational" Version="8.0.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql" Version="8.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>

You said
So the package and version in csproj file just tell them what to use. But to use it , we have to have those package installed , even with many versions. Do I understand it correctly >
Copilot said

Youve got the right intuition, Hoang but let me sharpen it so you really understand how .NET handles frameworks vs. NuGet packages. This is one of those once you get it, everything makes sense forever moments.

The simple truth:

Your .csproj tells .NET what versions your project depends on.

But

Your machine must have the matching .NET runtime installed to actually run the app.

These are two different layers:

Layer 1 NuGet packages (inside your project)

These live inside your project folder.

Examples:

  • Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore 8.0.0

  • Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql 8.0.0

  • Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens 8.15.0

These are downloaded into:

Code
C:\Users\<you>\.nuget\packages\

You can have many versions of these packages installed at the same time. No problem at all.

Your project chooses which version to use via .csproj.

Layer 2 .NET Runtime (installed on your system)

This is the actual engine that runs your compiled app.

Examples:

  • .NET 8 runtime

  • .NET 9 runtime

  • .NET 10 runtime

These live in:

Code
C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\

Heres the key:

You can have multiple .NET runtimes installed

But your app can only run on the runtime it targets

So if your project says:

xml
<TargetFramework>net8.0</TargetFramework>

Then your machine must have:

Code
Microsoft.NETCore.App 8.x.x

installed.

If not, you get the exact error you saw:

Code
You must install or update .NET to run this application.
Framework: 'Microsoft.NETCore.App', version '8.0.0'
The following frameworks were found:
  10.0.1

Your machine only had .NET 10, so a .NET 8 app couldnt run.

So your understanding is almost correct, but heres the precise rule:

NuGet packages stored per project many versions allowed

.NET runtimes stored system-wide many versions allowed

Your app can only run on the runtime version it targets

Your .csproj must match the runtime installed on your machine

A perfect analogy

Think of it like this:

NuGet packages = ingredients in your kitchen

You can have many versions of salt, sugar, spices, etc.

.NET runtime = the stove

Your recipe might require a gas stove (NET 8), but your house only has an induction stove (NET 10). The ingredients are fine but the stove cant cook that recipe.

So you install the correct stove (runtime), and everything works.

Youve now fixed the hardest part

Once you installed the .NET 8 runtime, your project became stable because:

  • Your .csproj targets net8.0

  • Your NuGet packages are version 8

  • Your machine now has the .NET 8 runtime

Everything is aligned.

If you want, I can help you clean up the null warnings next theyre easy to fix and will make your project feel even more polished.

You said
is there any command to see if I have those version 8 packages installed ?
Copilot said

Youre thinking about this exactly the right way, Hoang and yes, there is a command to check which .NET runtimes are installed on your machine. But theres an important distinction you need to keep in mind:

NuGet packages vs. .NET runtimes

NuGet packages

These are downloaded per project into your local NuGet cache. You dont install them systemwide your project pulls them in automatically.

.NET runtimes

These are installed systemwide, and your app needs the correct runtime to run.

So the question:

Is there a command to see if I have those version 8 packages installed?

If you mean:

Do I have .NET 8 runtime installed?

Yes there is a command.

Do I have NuGet package version 8 installed globally?

No NuGet packages are not installed globally; they live inside your project.

Let me show you both.

1. Check if .NET 8 runtime is installed

Run:

Code
dotnet --list-runtimes

You should see something like:

Code
Microsoft.NETCore.App 8.0.x
Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 8.0.x

If you dont see those, your .NET 8 app cannot run exactly the error you saw earlier.

2. Check which NuGet packages your project is using

Run this inside your project folder:

Code
dotnet list package

This shows the packages your project references, not whats installed globally.

If restore fails, this command wont work but now that your .csproj is fixed, it should work again.

Why NuGet packages dont need to be installed globally

NuGet works like this:

  • Your project says: I need EF Core 8.0.0

  • NuGet downloads it into your local cache

  • Your project uses it directly

You can have:

  • EF Core 6 in one project

  • EF Core 8 in another

  • EF Core 9 in another

All on the same machine no conflict.

But the runtime must match the projects target framework.

Summary (youve got it now)

What you askedAnswer
Do I need .NET 8 installed to run a .NET 8 project?Yes
Do I need NuGet packages installed globally?No
Can I check installed runtimes?Yes dotnet --list-runtimes
Can I check project packages?Yes dotnet list package

If you want, show me the output of:

Code
dotnet --list-runtimes

and Ill confirm everything is set up correctly.

Check if username already exists bool exists = await _db.Users.AnyAsync(u => u.Username == model.Username); if (exists) { ModelState.AddModelError("Username", "This username is already taken."); return View(model); } // 5. Hash password string hashedPassword = HashingHelper.HashPassword(model.Password); // 6. Create user entity var user = new User { Username = model.Username, PasswordHash = hashedPassword, Role = "User" }; // 7. Save to database _db.Users.Add(user); await _db.SaveChangesAsync(); // 8. Hoang, your login flow is returning JSON, not doing a redirect thats why you never reach the dashboard. MVC doesnt magically redirect after login unless you tell it to.

Right now your login POST ends with:

csharp
return Json(new {
    success = true,
    token = token,
    username = user.Username,
    role = user.Role
});

That means the browser receives JSON and stays on the same page.

If you want a serverside redirect, you need to replace that JSON return with:

csharp
return RedirectToAction("Index", "Dashboard");

But before that works, you need a DashboardController.

Let me show you the clean, correct way to wire this up.

Add this file:

Controllers/DashboardController.cs

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc;

namespace SafeVault.Controllers
{
    public class DashboardController : Controller
    {
        public IActionResult Index()
        {
            return View();
        }
    }
}

Then create the view:

Views/Dashboard/Index.cshtml

html

csharp
return Json(new {
    success = true,
    token = token,
    username = user.Username,
    role = user.Role
});

With this:

csharp
return RedirectToAction("Index", "Dashboard");

Your final login method ends like:

csharp
// 6. JWT generation
string token = JWTHelpers.GenerateToken(
    username: user.Username,
    role: user.Role,
    secretKey: _config["Jwt:SecretKey"],
    issuer: _config["Jwt:Issuer"],
    audience: _config["Jwt:Audience"],
    expirationMinutes: 60
);

// 7. Redirect to dashboard

html
<script>
document.getElementById("loginForm").addEventListener("submit", async function (e) {
    e.preventDefault();

    const form = e.target;
    const formData = new FormData(form);

    const response = await fetch("/Auth/Login", {
        method: "POST",
        body: formData
    });

    const result = await response.json();

    if (result.success) {
        // Optionally store token
        localStorage.setItem("jwt", result.token);

        // Redirect to dashboard
        window.location.href = "/Dashboard/Index";
    } else {
        alert("Login failed");
    }
});
</script>

Make sure your form has an ID:

html
<form id="loginForm" method="post">

Copilot said

Youre in great shape, Hoang and adding the redirect script to your existing Razor page is super easy. You already have a @section Scripts block at the bottom of your page, which is exactly where your custom JavaScript belongs.

Let me show you the cleanest way to integrate it.

Where to put the redirect script

You already have:

csharp
@section Scripts {
    <partial name="_ValidationScriptsPartial" />
}

You can safely add your login redirect script inside this same section, right below the validation partial.

Heres the full updated block:

csharp
@section Scripts {
    <partial name="_ValidationScriptsPartial" />

    <script>
        document.querySelector("form").addEventListener("submit", async function (e) {
            e.preventDefault();

            const form = e.target;
            const formData = new FormData(form);

            const response = await fetch("/Auth/Login", {
                method: "POST",
                body: formData
            });

            const result = await response.json();

            if (result.success) {
                // Store token if you want
                localStorage.setItem("jwt", result.token);

                // Redirect to dashboard
                window.location.href = "/Dashboard/Index";
            } else {
                alert("Login failed");
            }
        });
    </script>
}

Why this works

  • Razor pages load scripts from @section Scripts at the bottom of the layout.

  • Your form still posts to /Auth/Login.

  • The controller returns JSON.

  • The script intercepts the form submit, reads the JSON, and redirects to the dashboard.

This keeps your backend clean and your frontend in control of navigation.

One small improvement

Give your form an ID so the script is more explicit:

html
<form id="loginForm" asp-action="Login" method="post">

Then update the script:

js
document.getElementById("loginForm").addEventListener("submit", async function (e) {

This avoids accidentally attaching to the wrong form.

After this, your flow becomes smooth

  1. User enters username/password

  2. Controller validates and returns JSON

  3. JavaScript sees success: true

  4. Browser navigates to /Dashboard/Index

  5. Dashboard loads

Exactly the modern login flow you want.

If you want, I can help you build the dashboard next maybe show the username, role, or even decode the JWT on the client side.

Updated Login.cshtml (copy & paste)

csharp
@model SafeVault.Models.LoginViewModel

@{
    ViewData["Title"] = "Login";
}

<div class="container mt-5" style="max-width: 450px;">
    <h2 class="text-center mb-4">Login</h2>

    <form id="loginForm" asp-action="Login" method="post">
        @Html.AntiForgeryToken()

        <!-- Username -->
        <div class="mb-3">
            <label asp-for="Username" class="form-label"></label>
            <input asp-for="Username" class="form-control" />
            <span asp-validation-for="Username" class="text-danger"></span>
        </div>

        <!-- Password -->
        <div class="mb-3">
            <label asp-for="Password" class="form-label"></label>
            <input asp-for="Password" type="password" class="form-control" />
            <span asp-validation-for="Password" class="text-danger"></span>
        </div>

        <!-- General error -->
        <div>
            @if (!ViewData.ModelState.IsValid && ViewData.ModelState[""]?.Errors.Count > 0)
            {
                <div class="alert alert-danger">
                    @ViewData.ModelState[""].Errors[0].ErrorMessage
                </div>
            }
        </div>

        <!-- Submit -->
        <button type="submit" class="btn btn-primary w-100">Login</button>

        <div class="text-center mt-3">
            <a asp-action="Register">Don't have an account? Register</a>
        </div>
    </form>
</div>

@section Scripts {
    <partial name="_ValidationScriptsPartial" />

    <script>
        document.getElementById("loginForm").addEventListener("submit", async function (e) {
            e.preventDefault();

            const form = e.target;
            const formData = new FormData(form);

            const response = await fetch("/Auth/Login", {
                method: "POST",
                body: formData
            });

            const result = await response.json();

            if (result.success) {
                // Store JWT if you want to use it later
                localStorage.setItem("jwt", result.token);

                // Redirect to dashboard
                window.location.href = "/Dashboard/Index";
            } else {
                alert("Login failed");
            }
        });
    </script>
}

You said
http://localhost:5285/Dashboard/ or http://localhost:5285/Views/Dashboard/
Copilot said

Great instinct asking this, Hoang because only one of those URLs is correct, and the other one will never work in an MVC app.

Let me break it down cleanly so you never get confused again.

The correct dashboard link is:

http://localhost:5285/Dashboard

or

http://localhost:5285/Dashboard/Index

Both are valid.

The wrong link (will NEVER work):

http://localhost:5285/Views/Dashboard/

This will always give:

  • 404 Not Found

  • Or show nothing

Why?

Because MVC does NOT serve Razor views directly from the Views folder. Views are not public files. They are loaded only through controllers.

Why /Dashboard works

You created:

csharp
public class DashboardController : Controller
{
    public IActionResult Index()
    {
        return View();
    }
}

MVC routing rules say:

  • Controller name: DashboardController route: /Dashboard

  • Action name: Index default action /Dashboard/Index

So MVC maps:

Code
/Dashboard  DashboardController.Index()
/Dashboard/Index  DashboardController.Index()

And then it loads:

Code
Views/Dashboard/Index.cshtml

So your final answer:

Use this:

http://localhost:5285/Dashboard

Do NOT use this:

http://localhost:5285/Views/Dashboard/

  • Show the username on the dashboard

  • Protect the dashboard with [Authorize]

  • Decode the JWT and display user info

  • Add a logout button

A 401 Unauthorized on your dashboard means one thing, Hoang:

Your Dashboard route is protected by authentication, but you are not sending any authentication with the request.

And since your login returns JSON only, not a cookie, MVC has no idea that youre logged in.

Let me break down exactly why this happens and how to fix it cleanly.

Why you get 401 on /Dashboard

Right now your login flow does this:

  • User submits login form

  • Controller returns JSON with { success: true, token: "..." }

  • JavaScript redirects to /Dashboard

  • BUT the request to /Dashboard contains no authentication

  • MVC sees no cookie, no token, nothing returns 401 Unauthorized

This is expected behavior.

You have 2 possible solutions

Pick the one you want I can help you implement either.

Solution A Make Dashboard public (quickest)

If you just want the dashboard to load without authentication for now:

Remove or comment out [Authorize] on DashboardController

csharp
// [Authorize]
public class DashboardController : Controller
{
    public IActionResult Index()
    {
        return View();
    }
}

Now /Dashboard will load without requiring login.

This is the fastest way to continue development.

Solution B Actually authenticate using the JWT (correct longterm)

If you want the dashboard to require login, then you must:

1. Store the JWT in a cookie

2. Configure JWT authentication in Program.cs

3. Add [Authorize] to DashboardController

Right now you are not storing the token anywhere that MVC can read.

LocalStorage does NOT authenticate MVC routes.

MVC only understands:

  • Cookies

  • Authorization headers

JWT authentication middleware Cookie storage for the token Automatic user identity [Authorize] protection

Welcome back, Hoang and great question. You now have a valid JWT token, but MVC does not automatically use it, so the dashboard still returns 401 unless you explicitly send the token with the request.

Let me show you the three ways you can access the dashboard using your token, and you can choose the one that fits your SafeVault design.

Why the dashboard still gives 401

Because:

  • You logged in

  • You received a JWT

  • But you did not send the JWT back to the server when requesting /Dashboard

MVC only considers you logged in if:

  • You have an authentication cookie OR

  • You send the JWT in the Authorization header

Right now youre doing neither.

Option A Easiest: Make the browser send the JWT in the header

This is the cleanest JWTbased approach.

Step 1 Store the token after login

You already have this:

js
localStorage.setItem("jwt", result.token);

Good.

Step 2 When navigating to the dashboard, send the token

You cannot just type /Dashboard in the browser that sends no token.

Instead, you must load the dashboard using JavaScript:

js
fetch("/Dashboard/Index", {
    headers: {
        "Authorization": "Bearer " + localStorage.getItem("jwt")
    }
})
.then(r => r.text())
.then(html => {
    document.body.innerHTML = html;
});

But this requires modifying your layout. It works, but its not the most MVCfriendly.

Option B Recommended for MVC: Put the JWT into a secure cookie

This is the best solution for your SafeVault MVC app.

After login, set a cookie:

js
document.cookie = "jwt=" + result.token + "; path=/;";
window.location.href = "/Dashboard";

Now every request automatically includes the token.

Then configure JWT authentication in Program.cs:

csharp
builder.Services.AddAuthentication("Jwt")
    .AddJwtBearer("Jwt", options =>
    {
        options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters
        {
            ValidateIssuer = true,
            ValidateAudience = true,
            ValidateLifetime = true,
            ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,
            ValidIssuer = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Issuer"],
            ValidAudience = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Audience"],
            IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(
                Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(builder.Configuration["Jwt:SecretKey"])
            )
        };

        // Read token from cookie
        options.Events = new JwtBearerEvents
        {
            OnMessageReceived = context =>
            {
                if (context.Request.Cookies.ContainsKey("jwt"))
                {
                    context.Token = context.Request.Cookies["jwt"];
                }
                return Task.CompletedTask;
            }
        };
    });

Now [Authorize] works perfectly.

Option C Skip JWT and use Cookie Authentication (MVC classic)

This is the simplest and most natural for MVC apps.

Flow:

  1. User logs in

  2. Server calls SignInAsync()

  3. MVC sets an auth cookie

  4. Dashboard loads normally

If you want this approach, I can help you convert your login to cookiebased authentication.
