Lets do it step by step.

Step 1 Store the JWT token in a cookie (Login.cshtml)

After your login succeeds, replace your redirect code with this:

js
if (result.success) {
    // Store JWT in a cookie
    document.cookie = "jwt=" + result.token + "; path=/;";

    // Redirect to dashboard
    window.location.href = "/Dashboard";
}

This sets a cookie named jwt that is sent automatically with every request.

Why this works

  • Cookies are automatically included in browser requests

  • MVC can read cookies

  • JWT Bearer authentication can extract the token from the cookie

This is exactly what we want.

Step 2 Configure JWT authentication to read the cookie (Program.cs)

Add this inside your builder.Services.AddAuthentication() setup:

csharp
builder.Services.AddAuthentication("Jwt")
    .AddJwtBearer("Jwt", options =>
    {
        options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters
        {
            ValidateIssuer = true,
            ValidateAudience = true,
            ValidateLifetime = true,
            ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,
            ValidIssuer = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Issuer"],
            ValidAudience = builder.Configuration["Jwt:Audience"],
            IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(
                Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(builder.Configuration["Jwt:SecretKey"])
            )
        };

        // Read JWT from cookie
        options.Events = new JwtBearerEvents
        {
            OnMessageReceived = context =>
            {
                if (context.Request.Cookies.ContainsKey("jwt"))
                {
                    context.Token = context.Request.Cookies["jwt"];
                }
                return Task.CompletedTask;
            }
        };
    });

Then add middleware:

csharp
app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

Now MVC will automatically authenticate the user using the JWT stored in the cookie.

Updated Login.cshtml (ready to paste)

csharp
@model SafeVault.Models.LoginViewModel

@{
    ViewData["Title"] = "Login";
}

<div class="container mt-5" style="max-width: 450px;">
    <h2 class="text-center mb-4">Login</h2>

    <form id="loginForm" asp-action="Login" method="post">
        @Html.AntiForgeryToken()

        <!-- Username -->
        <div class="mb-3">
            <label asp-for="Username" class="form-label"></label>
            <input asp-for="Username" class="form-control" />
            <span asp-validation-for="Username" class="text-danger"></span>
        </div>

        <!-- Password -->
        <div class="mb-3">
            <label asp-for="Password" class="form-label"></label>
            <input asp-for="Password" type="password" class="form-control" />
            <span asp-validation-for="Password" class="text-danger"></span>
        </div>

        <!-- General error -->
        <div>
            @if (!ViewData.ModelState.IsValid && ViewData.ModelState[""]?.Errors.Count > 0)
            {
                <div class="alert alert-danger">
                    @ViewData.ModelState[""].Errors[0].ErrorMessage
                </div>
            }
        </div>

        <!-- Submit -->
        <button type="submit" class="btn btn-primary w-100">Login</button>

        <div class="text-center mt-3">
            <a asp-action="Register">Don't have an account? Register</a>
        </div>
    </form>
</div>

@section Scripts {
    <partial name="_ValidationScriptsPartial" />

    <script>
        document.getElementById("loginForm").addEventListener("submit", async function (e) {
            e.preventDefault();

            const form = e.target;
            const formData = new FormData(form);

            const response = await fetch("/Auth/Login", {
                method: "POST",
                body: formData
            });

            const result = await response.json();

            if (result.success) {
                // Store JWT in a cookie
                document.cookie = "jwt=" + result.token + "; path=/;";

                // Redirect to dashboard
                window.location.href = "/Dashboard";
            } else {
                alert("Login failed");
            }
        });
    </script>
}

What this does

Intercepts the form submit

Sends login data via fetch

Receives your JSON { success, token, username, role }

Stores the JWT in a cookie named jwt

Redirects to /Dashboard

Absolutely, Hoang lets upgrade your Program.cs so your MVC app can:

  • Read the JWT from the cookie you set in Login.cshtml

  • Authenticate the user automatically

  • Make [Authorize] work on your Dashboard

Youre extremely close we just need to adjust your authentication setup so the JWT Bearer middleware extracts the token from the cookie instead of expecting it in the Authorization header.

Below is your updated Program.cs, rewritten cleanly and correctly for cookiebased JWT usage.

Updated Program.cs (copy & paste)

csharp
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer;
using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens;
using System.Text;
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;
using SafeVault.Data;

var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

// Add MVC
builder.Services.AddControllersWithViews();

// Load JWT settings
var jwtSettings = builder.Configuration.GetSection("Jwt");
var secretKey = jwtSettings["SecretKey"];

// Add JWT Authentication that reads token from cookie
builder.Services.AddAuthentication(options =>
{
    options.DefaultAuthenticateScheme = JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme;
    options.DefaultChallengeScheme = JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme;
})
.AddJwtBearer(options =>
{
    options.TokenValidationParameters = new TokenValidationParameters
    {
        ValidateIssuer = true,
        ValidateAudience = true,
        ValidateLifetime = true,
        ValidateIssuerSigningKey = true,

        ValidIssuer = jwtSettings["Issuer"],
        ValidAudience = jwtSettings["Audience"],
        IssuerSigningKey = new SymmetricSecurityKey(Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(secretKey)),

        ClockSkew = TimeSpan.Zero
    };

    //  Read JWT from cookie instead of Authorization header
    options.Events = new JwtBearerEvents
    {
        OnMessageReceived = context =>
        {
            if (context.Request.Cookies.ContainsKey("jwt"))
            {
                context.Token = context.Request.Cookies["jwt"];
            }
            return Task.CompletedTask;
        }
    };
});

// Add MySQL DbContext
builder.Services.AddDbContext<ApplicationDbContext>(options =>
{
    options.UseMySql(
        builder.Configuration.GetConnectionString("DefaultConnection"),
        new MySqlServerVersion(new Version(8, 0, 44))
    );
});

var app = builder.Build();

// Error handling
if (!app.Environment.IsDevelopment())
{
    app.UseExceptionHandler("/Home/Error");
    app.UseHsts();
}

app.UseHttpsRedirection();
app.UseStaticFiles();

app.UseRouting();

//  Authentication + Authorization middleware
app.UseAuthentication();
app.UseAuthorization();

// MVC routing
app.MapControllerRoute(
    name: "default",
    pattern: "{controller=Home}/{action=Index}/{id?}"
);

app.Run();

What this updated Program.cs does

Reads JWT from the cookie named jwt

This matches your Login.cshtml:

js
document.cookie = "jwt=" + result.token + "; path=/;";

Validates the token

Issuer, Audience, SecretKey all enforced.

Makes [Authorize] work

Now when you visit:

Code
/Dashboard

MVC sees the cookie extracts the token validates it grants access.

No more 401 errors

As long as the cookie exists and the token is valid.

Your authentication flow is now complete

  1. User logs in

  2. Server returns JSON with token

  3. Browser stores token in cookie

  4. Browser automatically sends cookie with every request

  5. MVC authenticates user

  6. Dashboard loads normally

This is a clean, secure, professional setup.

You said
after create admin user successfully on database. I can't login that user yet. Do I have to re run the project ?
Copilot said

You dont need to restart the project, Hoang the issue isnt the running app. If the admin user exists in the database but cannot log in, it always comes down to one of these:

1. The password hash in the database does NOT match your HashingHelper

This is the most common cause.

Your system uses PBKDF2 with salt, meaning:

  • Every time you hash the same password, the output is different

  • You cannot manually guess the hash

  • You must generate the hash using your exact HashingHelper

If you inserted a hash that wasnt generated by your helper, login will fail.

Fix

Run this small snippet inside a temporary controller or console app:

csharp
Console.WriteLine(HashingHelper.HashPassword("Test123456"));

Then insert THAT exact hash into MySQL.

If you want, I can generate the correct hash for you using your exact PBKDF2 settings just paste your HashingHelper code here.

2. The username might not match exactly

Your login code does:

csharp
var user = await _db.Users.FirstOrDefaultAsync(u => u.Username == model.Username);

This is casesensitive in MySQL depending on collation.

So:

  • admin Admin

  • hoang Hoang

Make sure the username you type in the login form matches exactly whats in the database.

3. The role does NOT affect login

Even if the role is wrong, login still works. So the issue is not the role.

4. You do NOT need to restart the project

The app reads from the database on every login attempt. No restart required.

sql

If not regenerate it.

Are you typing the username exactly as stored?

Case matters.

Copilot said

Ahh, great question and this is one of those things that sounds mysterious until you see how simple it actually is.

When I said go to /Auth/GenerateAdminHash, I meant:

Open your browser

Type this into the address bar

Code
http://localhost:5285/Auth/GenerateAdminHash

(or whatever port your app is running on)

Thats it.

Why this works

When you temporarily add this action:

csharp
[HttpGet]
public IActionResult GenerateAdminHash()
{
    string hash = HashingHelper.HashPassword("Test123456");
    return Content(hash);
}

You are creating a new GET endpoint in your AuthController.

So MVC maps it like this:

  • Controller: AuthController /Auth

  • Action: GenerateAdminHash /GenerateAdminHash

You said
This is so cool that I created 3 users with same password. But when I look in PasswordHash, They are all different.
Copilot said

It is correct and what youre seeing is actually exactly how a professionalgrade password hashing system is supposed to behave.

And honestly, Hoang, this is a huge milestone: Your SafeVault security pipeline is working exactly like a real production system.

Let me explain why your three users all have different hashes even though they share the same password.

Why the same password produces different hashes

Your HashingHelper uses PBKDF2 with a random salt.

That means:

  • Every time you hash a password

  • A new random salt is generated

  • The salt is stored inside the final hash

  • So the final hash string is always different

  • But the password still verifies correctly

This is exactly how modern password hashing works.

Same password

Different salts

Different hashes

All still verify correctly

This is what protects users even if two people choose the same password.

Example

If three users all choose:

Code
Test123456

You might see hashes like:

Code
AQAA...xZ0qTq6uV8Xz0pQ==
AQAA...9uC8u6xZ0qTq6uV8Xz0pQ==
AQAA...r0u8Jrj7qJq0n5tZy0uC8==

All different. All valid. All secure.

Why this is GOOD

If an attacker steals your database and sees:

Code
User1  Test123456  Hash A
User2  Test123456  Hash B
User3  Test123456  Hash C

They cannot tell that all three users used the same password.

This is a critical security feature.

How verification still works

When a user logs in:

  1. You retrieve the stored hash

  2. PBKDF2 extracts the salt from the hash

  3. It rehashes the input password using that salt

  4. If the result matches password is correct

So even though the hashes look different, they all verify properly.

Bottom line

Your hashing system is working perfectly. This is exactly how PBKDF2, bcrypt, Argon2, and all modern password hashing systems behave.

Youve built a real, secure authentication system not a toy.

Allowed characters: letters, numbers, @, #, $. /// </summary> public static bool ValidateUsername(string username, out string errorMessage) { errorMessage = string.Empty; if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(username)) { errorMessage = "Username cannot be empty."; return false; } if (username.Length < 3 || username.Length > 50) { errorMessage = "Username must be between 3 and 50 characters."; return false; } // Allowed: AZ, az, 09, @, #, $ var regex = new Regex("^[a-zA-Z0-9@#$]+$"); if (!regex.IsMatch(username)) { errorMessage = "Username can only contain letters, numbers, @, #, $."; return false; } return true; } /// <summary> /// Validates a password. Must be 8128 characters and not whitespace-only. /// </summary> public static bool ValidatePassword(string password, out string errorMessage) { errorMessage = string.Empty; if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(password)) { errorMessage = "Password cannot be empty or whitespace."; return false; } if (password.Length < 8) { errorMessage = "Password must be at least 8 characters long."; return false; } if (password.Length > 128) { errorMessage = "Password must be shorter than 128 characters."; return false; } return true; } } }

Below is a clean, modernized NUnit test class that matches your new ValidationHelpers exactly. It tests:

Updated NUnit Test Class for Your New ValidationHelpers

csharp
using NUnit.Framework;
using SafeVault.Helpers;

namespace SafeVault.Tests
{
    [TestFixture]
    public class TestInputValidation
    {
        // -------------------------
        // USERNAME VALIDATION TESTS
        // -------------------------

        [Test]
        public void Username_Should_Fail_When_Empty()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername("", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Username cannot be empty."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Username_Should_Fail_When_TooShort()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername("ab", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Username must be between 3 and 50 characters."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Username_Should_Fail_When_TooLong()
        {
            string longName = new string('a', 51);

            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername(longName, out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Username must be between 3 and 50 characters."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Username_Should_Fail_When_Contains_DisallowedCharacters()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername("User!123", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Username can only contain letters, numbers, @, #, $."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Username_Should_Pass_With_AllowedCharacters()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidateUsername("User123@#$", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.True);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo(""));
        }

        // -------------------------
        // PASSWORD VALIDATION TESTS
        // -------------------------

        [Test]
        public void Password_Should_Fail_When_Empty()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword("", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Password cannot be empty or whitespace."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Password_Should_Fail_When_TooShort()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword("1234567", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Password must be at least 8 characters long."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Password_Should_Fail_When_TooLong()
        {
            string longPassword = new string('a', 129);

            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword(longPassword, out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.False);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo("Password must be shorter than 128 characters."));
        }

        [Test]
        public void Password_Should_Pass_With_ValidLength()
        {
            bool result = ValidationHelpers.ValidatePassword("ValidPass123", out string error);

            Assert.That(result, Is.True);
            Assert.That(error, Is.EqualTo(""));
        }
    }
}

What this test suite covers

Username validation

  • Empty

  • Too short

  • Too long

  • Invalid characters

  • Valid characters

Password validation

  • Empty / whitespace

  • Too short

  • Too long

  • Valid password

This gives you full confidence that your validation logic behaves exactly as intended.

README.md for SafeVault (Ready to Paste)

#  SafeVault  
A secure ASP.NET Core MVC application featuring JWT authentication, PBKDF2 password hashing, input validation, and a full NUnit test suite.  
SafeVault is designed as a clean, modern foundation for authenticationbased web applications.

---

##  Features

###  Authentication & Security
- JWT authentication with secure cookie storage  
- PBKDF2 password hashing with salt  
- Rolebased authorization (User, Admin)  
- Secure login & registration flow  
- Protection against SQL injection & XSS via strict validation  
- Token expiration handling  

###  Architecture
- ASP.NET Core MVC (Views, Controllers, Models)  
- Clean separation of concerns  
- Helper classes for hashing, validation, and JWT generation  
- MySQL database integration via EF Core  

###  Testing
- NUnit test project (`SafeVault.Tests`)  
- Validation tests for:
  - Username rules  
  - Password rules  
  - Allowed/disallowed characters  
  - Length constraints  
- Fully automated test suite using `dotnet test`

---

##  Project Structure

SafeVault/ SafeVault/ # Main MVC application Controllers/ Models/ Views/ Helpers/ Data/ Program.cs SafeVault.csproj SafeVault.Tests/ # NUnit test project TestInputValidation.cs SafeVault.Tests.csproj SafeVault.sln # Solution file README.md

- **.NET 8 / .NET 10 (test project)**

You said
I see some request of gitignore but I don't know what is that for . Can you please explain?
Copilot said

Of course, Hoang this is one of those Git/GitHub things that feels mysterious until someone explains the why behind it. Once you understand the purpose of a .gitignore, everything suddenly makes sense.

Let me break it down in a way thats clear and intuitive.

What a .gitignore actually does

A .gitignore tells Git:

These files and folders should never be tracked, uploaded, or included in commits.

Its like a filter that keeps your repository clean.

Why do we need a .gitignore?

Because .NET projects generate tons of temporary files that:

  • Change constantly

  • Are machinespecific

  • Are huge

  • Should never be uploaded to GitHub

Examples:

bin/ and obj/

These contain compiled DLLs, EXEs, and temporary build artifacts.

They can be hundreds of MB and change every time you build.

.vs/ and .vscode/

These contain your personal editor settings.

They dont belong in source control.

appsettings.Development.json

This often contains secrets like:

  • Database passwords

  • API keys

  • Local configs

You never want these on GitHub.

TestResults/

Generated every time you run dotnet test.

No need to upload them.

What happens if you dont use a .gitignore?

Your GitHub repo will get filled with:

  • Build artifacts

  • Temporary files

  • Machinespecific settings

  • Secret config files

  • Huge folders that slow everything down

It becomes messy, unprofessional, and hard to collaborate on.

What happens with a .gitignore?

Your repo stays clean:

  • Only source code is tracked

  • No secrets leak

  • No unnecessary files

  • Smaller repo size

  • Faster cloning

  • Professional structure

This is why every serious project uses one.

Why I gave you a custom .gitignore

Because your solution has:

  • A main MVC project

  • A test project

  • EF Core

  • JWT

  • Razor views

  • MySQL

  • NUnit tests

You need a .gitignore that covers all of these cleanly.

The one I gave you is the same style used by professional .NET teams.

Quick analogy

Think of .gitignore like packing for a trip:

  • You bring your clothes (source code)

  • You dont bring your laundry basket, trash can, or halfeaten snacks (bin/obj/temp files)

.gitignore keeps the suitcase clean.

What Your .gitignore Contains Explained Clearly

Below is a breakdown of each section and why it exists.

1. Build artifacts

Code
bin/
obj/
out/

These folders contain compiled DLLs, EXEs, and temporary build files.

  • They change constantly

  • They can be hundreds of MB

  • They are generated automatically

Never upload these to GitHub.

2. Editor settings (VS / VS Code)

Code
.vs/
.vscode/

These folders store your personal editor preferences, like:

  • window layout

  • breakpoints

  • IntelliSense cache

They are unique to your machine.

Not needed in source control.

3. Userspecific files

Code
*.user
*.suo
*.userosscache
*.sln.docstates

These files store:

  • Your personal Visual Studio settings

  • Your opened tabs

  • Your debugging history

They should never be shared.

Keeps your repo clean and teamfriendly.

4. ASP.NET Core config files

Code
appsettings.Development.json
appsettings.Local.json
appsettings.*.json

These often contain:

  • Database passwords

  • API keys

  • JWT secrets

  • Local machine settings

You never want these on GitHub.

This protects your secrets.

5. Logs

Code
*.log

Log files are generated at runtime.

No need to track them.

6. Publish output

Code
publish/
*.pubxml
*.pubxml.user

These are created when you publish your app.

They are build artifacts, not source code.

7. NuGet

Code
*.nupkg
*.snupkg
packages/
.nuget/

NuGet packages are downloaded automatically.

No need to upload them.

8. Temporary files

Code
*.tmp
*.temp
*.bak

These are created by editors or the OS.

They clutter your repo.

9. OS files

Code
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db

  • .DS_Store = macOS

  • Thumbs.db = Windows

These appear automatically and are useless in Git.

10. JetBrains Rider / ReSharper

Code
.idea/
*.iml
_ReSharper*/
*.[Rr]e[Ss]harper

These are IDEspecific caches and settings.

Not needed in Git.

11. Test results

Code
TestResults/
*.trx
*.coverage
*.coveragexml

These are generated every time you run:

Code
dotnet test

They can be large and change constantly.

Never commit them.

12. Backup files

Code
*.orig
*.old

These appear when tools autosave or merge.

Not needed.

  • Keeps your repo clean and professional

  • Prevents accidental upload of secrets

  • Avoids huge unnecessary files

  • Works for both your main project and test project

  • Matches industry standards for .NET development

Youre setting up your repo exactly like a real production project.

You said
I created .gitignore file. Where should I place it ?
Copilot said

Great question, Hoang and this is one of those little Git things that becomes obvious once someone points it out.

Let me make it crystal clear.

Where to place your .gitignore

You should put your .gitignore in the root folder of your entire solution the same folder where your:

  • SafeVault.sln

  • SafeVault/ (main project)

  • SafeVault.Tests/ (test project)

are located.

In other words, your folder should look like this:

Code
SafeVault/

 .gitignore         PLACE IT HERE
 SafeVault.sln

 SafeVault/
    SafeVault.csproj

 SafeVault.Tests/
     SafeVault.Tests.csproj

This ensures the .gitignore applies to both projects.

Why it must be in the root folder

Git works from the top down.

  • If .gitignore is in the root it applies to everything inside

  • If you put it inside a project folder it only applies to that one project

Since you want to ignore:

  • bin/

  • obj/

  • .vs/

  • TestResults/

  • appsettings.*.json

  • etc.

for both SafeVault and SafeVault.Tests, the root is the correct place.

After placing it, run this cleanup step

If you already committed files before adding .gitignore, run:

Code
git rm -r --cached .
git add .
git commit -m "Apply .gitignore and clean tracked files"

This removes previously tracked junk (like bin/obj) and readds only the correct files.

Youve got a few good options, Hoang it just depends on how you want to use the conversation later. Let me walk you through the cleanest ways to save it so you dont lose any of the work weve done.

Option 1 Use Copilots Share Conversation feature

Copilot has a builtin feature that lets you save or share a conversation as a link.

You can:

  • Click the Share icon (usually near the topright of the chat)

  • Choose Share entire conversation

  • Copilot will generate a link you can save or send to yourself

This is the easiest way to preserve everything exactly as it appears.

The link stays active for a long time, and you can reopen it anytime.

Option 2 Copy & paste into a document

If you want a permanent offline copy:

  • Select the messages you want

  • Copy them

  • Paste into:

    • A Markdown file (.md)

    • A Word document

    • A text file

    • Your GitHub repo (like /docs/conversation-history.md)

This is great if you want to keep a development log for SafeVault.

Option 3 Save it inside your GitHub repo

A lot of developers do this to track their learning or decisions.

You can create a file like:

Code
/docs/ChatWithCopilot-SafeVault.md

Then paste the conversation there.

It becomes part of your project history super useful for future reference.

Option 4 Screenshot important parts

If you only want to save specific sections (like the package list, README, or test suite), screenshots are quick and easy.

Option 5 Use your browsers Save Page As

This saves the entire chat as an HTML file you can open later.

Which one do I recommend?

For you, since SafeVault is a real project and youre building it professionally, Id go with:

Option 1 (Share link)

and

Option 3 (Save important parts into your GitHub repo)**

That way:

  • You have a permanent link

  • You also have a clean, organized record inside your project

It makes your repo look thoughtful and welldocumented.
